questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with an over-activation in the complement pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hereditary angioedema

 

Option C:

 

Hereditary angioedema is a rare genetic disorder that is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, a protein involved in the complement pathway. This defect leads to uncontrolled activation of the complement pathway, resulting in excessive release of bradykinin, which causes recurrent episodes of swelling in various parts of the body.

 

Hereditary Angioedema (HAE) is a genetic disorder due to a deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor (C1-INH), which normally regulates the complement and contact systems. The lack of functional C1-INH leads to uncontrolled activation of the complement pathway, excessive production of bradykinin, and recurrent episodes of swelling.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): SLE is an autoimmune disease characterized by the production of autoantibodies that form immune complexes. These complexes can trigger the complement system, often leading to complement depletion. It is not typically associated with an over-activation of the complement pathway.

 

Option B. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS is a chronic autoimmune, inflammatory neurological disease that primarily affects the central nervous system. The complement system may play a role in the pathology of MS; however, it is not characterized by over-activation of the complement pathway.

 

Option D. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease with a complex pathogenesis involving the immune system. While the complement system may be activated as part of the inflammatory process in psoriasis, the disease is not primarily associated with an over-activation of the complement pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HAE is associated with over-activation of the complement pathway due to C1 inhibitor deficiency, leading to excessive bradykinin release and recurrent angioedema.

 

HAE:

 

Autosomal dominant disease

 

C1-INH normally stops spontaneous activation of:

 

  • C1 (classical pathway)
  • Kallikrein → which generates bradykinin

 

Without C1-INH:

 

  • Classical pathway is continuously activated → consumes complement (↓ C4, ↓ C2)
  • Over-production of bradykinin → vasodilation, edema

 

Clinically → patients have recurrent non-pitting angioedema (face, extremities, GI tract → can cause severe abdominal pain)

questions.text: Which of the following complement component can be activated is both common as well as alternative pathways?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C3

 

Option C:

The complement proteins can be activated by 3 pathways; classical, lectin and alternate pathways. Terminal pathway is common to the first three pathways and is present at the level of post activation stage of C3. It eventually leads to the membrane attack complex that lyses cells.

 

C3 is the central component of the complement system and can be activated by all three pathways: classical, lectin, and alternative. The cleavage oF C3 into C3a and C3b is a crucial step in the activation of the complement system.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C1 is the first component of the classical pathway of complement activation. It is not involved in the alternative pathway, which is initiated by spontaneous hydrolysis or microbial surface constituents.

 

Option B. C2 is part of the classical and lectin pathways. It forms a complex with C4 to produce the C3 convertase C4b2a. C2 is not involved in the alternative pathway.

 

Option D. C4 is involved in the classical and lectin pathways where, along with C2, it forms the C3 convertase. It is not part of the alternative pathway, which bypasses C4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3 is a key component in the complement system that is activated by all three pathways: classical, lectin, and alternative. Its activation is pivotal in the complement-mediated immune response, including opsonization and formation of the membrane attack complex.
